Furfural is an important biobased building block molecule to produce several value-added compounds for the fine chemical industry, biofuels, and biopolymers through a catalytic pathway. Developing cheaper and more sustainable catalysts to promote furfural conversion reactions is imperative to meet the Green Chemistry principles and obtain biobased products through greener routes. In this sense, sewage sludge-derived biochars emerge as promising materials that catalyze furfural conversion reactions since they possess acid and basic surface sites due to their high metal content and organic structure. This paper reports the employment of two sewage sludge-derived biochars as catalysts for furfural conversion, an encouraging application for these solids with severe environmental concerns. These materials were fully characterized regarding their composition, structure, textural, morphological, acidic, and surface properties, displaying the presence of acid (Lewis and Brønsted) and basic sites. These biochars presented good activity for converting furfural (26.5–68.8%) and high selectivity to furfuryl alcohol (43.6–90.6%). In addition, other value-added products were observed, such as furfural-derived ethers, ester, and ketone. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Sewage sludge Biochar Furfural Biomass Furfuryl alcohol Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, biomass valorization has become an important research field since the demand for clean technologies and pathways to obtain chemicals has grown fast, especially to substitute petroleum derivatives. In that approach, biomass can be chemically converted into several essential products for industry, such as furfuryl alcohol, levulinic acid, furoic acid, and many others that can be applied in fuel production and construction, pharmaceutical, and many others industrials sectors [1–3]. Several platform molecules can be obtained from different lignocellulosic biomass fractions, and one of the most promising building blocks is furfural (FUR) [4–6]. This compound is a precursor in several value-added chemical syntheses, for example, furfuryl alcohol (FA), used mainly in the fuel industry and can produce resins for the construction sector. Furfuryl esters produced by FUR oxidation are essential flavoring agents in the food industry [7]. Some larger molecules derived from FUR, such as furfuryl ethers, are critical for developing fuels, especially biodiesel, aviation, and rocket fuel production [8]. In this way, heterogeneous catalysts increase these processes' sustainable character and should be highly efficient, stable, and reusable [9]. A wide range of materials have been proposed in the literature for FUR conversion, such as zeolites [10,11], silicas- [12,13] and carbon-based materials [14], metal nanoparticles [15–17], and single-atom catalysts [18,19]. Nevertheless, manufacturing these catalysts is often difficult, expensive, generates hazardous residues, and uses reactants and methods with considerable environmental concerns. Within this scenario of reducing these concerns, biomass also emerges as a promising feedstock to produce more sustainable catalysts [20,21,19]. In this context, biochars are remarkable materials because of their facile synthesis. These materials have a unique structure and desired properties for their application as catalysts, such as porous structures and functional groups [22,23]. Biochars are materials produced from the biomass pyrolysis process under controlled conditions, and their structure comprises organic (polycondensed rings and aliphatic moieties) and ash. These solids are found in the literature for the conversion of biomass-derived compounds, in which they are mainly applied as support. For instance, Lee and co-workers reviewed different biochars for biomass conversion reactions as catalysts for transesterification, tar removal, and xylose hydrolysis [24]. In addition, Fuente-Hernández and co-workers also reported a platinum catalyst supported on biochar for FUR hydrogenation to FA [25]. However, those authors applied harsh conditions such as temperature and hydrogen pressure to achieve a high selectivity to FA. The obtention of sewage sludge biochar (SSB) is a promising pathway to solve a crucial environmental issue assigned to this type of biomass since several tons of this material are produced annually in highly developed cities [26,27]. In addition, this biomass is typically recognized for possessing a high heavy metal and microbial content and thus being a hazardous chemical and pathogen source [28]. The sustainable handling of sewage sludge using recycling alternatives is imperative to minimize the risks to human health and the environment. The SSBs are promising materials for catalysis due to Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, which are typically required for FUR conversion [29]. In such a manner, Agrafioti and co-workers described that these materials usually have high metal contents and an organic porous structure, showing that SSB has an intrinsic Lewis acidity [31]. Besides, the organic fraction of biochar also presents Brønsted acid and basic sites, as reported by Li and co-workers [31]. Considering the above explanations and the promising application of SSBs as catalysts, this work aims to explore two different SSBs as more sustainable catalysts for FUR conversion. It is essential to mention that, to the best of our knowledge, SSBs have never been reported as catalysts for FUR upgrading before, opening a window of new possibilities. This study proposes the achievement of greener catalysts for lignocellulosic biomass-derived compounds and solves a substantial environmental issue regarding the correct disposal of these sludges. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Except for pyridine (previously distilled), all chemicals used in this study were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich® and employed without further treatment or purification. 2.2 Biochar obtention The sewage sludges were collected from the Rio de Janeiro treatment station in two distinct stages: before (raw sewage sludge) and after (treated sewage sludge) flocculation. These sewage sludges originated their respective biochars: raw sewage sludge biochar (RSB) and treated sludge biochar (TSB). Both biochars were obtained by a previously reported method [32]; the sludges were dried at 105 °C until no variation in their mass was observed. Then, the pyrolysis was performed at the following conditions: 380 °C, 15 °C/min, N2 atmosphere, and 2 h of reaction, generating RSB and TSB. 2.3 Characterization The biochars’ overall metal contents were determined by microwave-induced optical emission spectrometry (MIP OES) using an Agilent 4210 MP AES spectrometer after microwave-assisted sample digestion with concentrated nitric acid. Sample digestion was performed in a Berghof (Eningen, Germany) microwave oven, model Speedwave, equipped with TFM® DAK-100 flasks, using a method proposed by own Berghof (and stored in the instrument memory) for digestion of coal (Table S1). In addition, to identify other elements in biochars, the X-ray fluorescence technique (EDX-720 Shimadzu) was employed with a step of 0.02 under vacuum with an Rh source at 50 kV, 30 μA, and 100 s of irradiation. X-ray diffraction patterns were obtained using a Bruker D8 diffractometer with a CuKα source (1.5406 Å) ranging from 5 to 90° with a 0.01°/s step. The crystalline phases were identified using the method Crystal Match!© software. The samples were characterized by attenuated total reflection infrared spectroscopy (FTIR-ATR) in a Varian 660 – IR spectrometer. The spectra were collected between 600 and 4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) was performed in Shimadzu DTG-60 equipment, using alumina crucibles in a synthetic air atmosphere (50 mL/min) at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The elemental analysis was performed to quantify carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen, and oxygen (obtained by subtracting the masses) using a Perkin Elmer Elementary Analysis 2400 pre-calibrated with an acetanilide standard. The textural properties were assessed by N2 physisorption at 77 K using a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 apparatus. Before the analyses, the samples were dried at 200 °C for 24 h under vacuum to remove water and other adsorbed gasses. Scanning Electronic Microscopy (SEM) coupled with Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy was performed using JEOL 7100F microscope. The XPS analyses were performed in ultra-high vacuum equipment (pressure: 10–7 Pa; Scienta Omicron GmbH, Taunusstein, Germany), using a non-monochromatic Al Kα (hν = 1486.6 eV) X-ray source, operated at the anode voltage of 15 kV and filament current of 20 mA. The high-resolution spectra for the O, N, Ca, C, Si, Fe, and Al were obtained with a pass energy of 20 eV. A charge neutralizer system, i.e., a flood gun operated at 3 V tension, emission current 1 μA, was used to eliminate charge accumulation effects. The C1s signal in aliphatic molecules (285 eV) was used for calibration using CasaXPS® software. Characterizing and estimating acidity values in biochars, especially those from sewage sludge is a challenging task for two reasons: (i) the acidity of these materials is not as high as in zeolites or functionalized silicas, and the use of conventional benchtop titration methods are complex [33]; (ii) the thermal stability of biochars is low and thus turning difficult to apply some standard techniques, such as TPD-NH3 or FTIR-pyridine with temperature programming [34]. This way, alternatives for quantifying the total acidity of SSBs, including the Lewis and Brønsted acid site speciation, are necessary to estimate such values. Here, we combined qualitative speciation of acid sites through FTIR-pyridine adsorption and quantitative total acid determination using liquid pyridine adsorption followed by TGA/DTA analyses already reported by Garcia and co-workers [35]. This method is based on the weight loss difference between the material before and after the adsorption of liquid pyridine, thus allowing the calculation of the amount of chemisorbed pyridine. The acidities of biochars were obtained as follows: 100 mg of each biochar were dispersed in 6.5 mL of distilled pyridine for 24 h at room temperature. The samples were filtered and dried, and then thermogravimetric analysis was employed. The acidity values were calculated using Eq. (1). (1) A c i d i t y ( m o l g ) Where wcatpy is the total weight loss of the catalyst after pyridine adsorption (neglecting the physisorbed pyridine, i.e., at temperature lower than 200 °C), wcat is the weight loss before pyridine adsorption, MMpy is the molar mass of pyridine and wdcat is the mass of dried catalyst (obtained at 200 °C). It is worth mentioning that physisorbed pyridine (values below 300 °C) was not used for the total acidity calculations for both biochars. The amount of Brønsted (B) and Lewis (L) acid sites of the biochars was determined by FTIR analysis of in situ adsorbed pyridine using a Bruker spectrometer (Vertex 70) equipped with an MCT detector and a transmission cell with a CaF2 window. For the analyses, a 10 mg sample pellet (pressed with 5 tons) was pre-treated at 250 °C under an argon atmosphere (100 mL/min) for 1 h. Then, the system was cooled to 150 °C, and the sample was saturated with pyridine vapor. The excess and physically adsorbed pyridine were purged with argon (100 mL/min). FTIR spectra were collected at 150 °C with a resolution of 4 cm−1 in the region of 4000 to 1000 cm−1. Next, the spectra from samples with and without adsorbed pyridine were subtracted [36]. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation A typical catalytic evaluation was performed according to a previous procedure reported in the literature [10–12]. For that, 50 mg of each biochar was added to 750 μL of isopropanol, 28 μL of FUR at 130 °C for 24 h in an Ace pressure tube®. Next, the liquid fraction was analyzed by GC-MS (GC-MS QP2010 Plus Shimadzu using a Supelcowax 8 column), and the following products were identified: (i) furfuryl alcohol (FA), (ii) 2-(isopropoxymethyl)furan (PMF), (iii) isopropyl furan-2-carboxylate (IPF), (iv) 2,2′-(oxybis(methylene))difuran (DFE), (v) (E)−4-(furan-2-yl)but-3-en-2-one (FBA). The recycled catalysts were also characterized by thermogravimetric analysis, N2 physisorption, X-ray diffraction, and Infrared spectroscopy. An initial catalytic run was performed employing RSB and TSB biochars as catalysts following a previously reported procedure [10–12]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Biochar characterization The FTIR experiments (Fig. 1a) confirm the formation of an organic biochar structure since both materials (RSB and TSB) presented bands assigned to stretching and bending, such as aromatic C=C (1614 and 1580 cm−1), aliphatic CH (2990 cm−1), and oxygenated CO (1020 cm−1) and OH (3610 cm−1) groups [23,37]. TGA measurements for both materials showed an initial mass loss from 25 °C to 150 °C assigned to the desorption of physisorbed water molecules from the biochar structure, and the mass loss from 150 °C to 560 °C was due to organic matter oxidation representing a 30.4% loss for RSB and 32.5% for TSB. From the TGA curves, it is possible to observe a slight difference between RSB and TSB ash contents showing that pre-treatment employed to produce TSB (flocculation and centrifugation in the sewage treatment station) can reduce the organic matter in the sewage sludge, as expected. In addition, lower thermal stability of the TSB material can be observed compared to the RSB due to a higher ash content in the latter material [31,33]. Both biochars were evaluated regarding their composition and pyrolysis yield as shown in Table 1 . The results demonstrate that these materials are mainly comprised of ash, i.e., inorganic compounds, as expected. However, both materials have a significant carbon content, suggesting that biochar organic structures were formed due to pyrolysis. Previous studies show similar values for SSB materials, in which the organic portion commonly represents the minor part of the biochar structure [30,38–40,23]. The aromaticity values (H/C ratios) were higher than 0.7, indicating that these materials do not have high concentrations of aromatic and polycondensate organic compounds. According to the European Biochar Certificate, these values suggest that the biochars structures might contain some residual sewage sludge agreeing with the pyrolisis yield observed for both materials [38]. This behavior is related to the low-temperature pyrolysis producing biochar with lower concentrations of aromatic compounds while the pyrolysis yield increases. Furthermore, the stability values (O/C ratios) follow the EBC parameter of 0.4, suggesting that no unstable oxygenated compounds were formed instead of the typical biochar structure [30,38–40,23]. Since the RSB and TSB biochars presented a high ashes content, the XRF analyses were employed to identify other elements in samples, and the results are displayed in Table S2. The analyses showed relevant contents of silicon, aluminum, iron, calcium, sulfur, phosphorous, potassium, titanium, and zinc. All these elements were reported for similar SSBs, especially sulfur, phosphorous, and potassium which are common in several biochars [37,38]. The MIP OES technique was employed to quantify the overall metal content in biochars. As Table 2 shows, a significant range of calcium, iron, and aluminum was found in both biochars, whereas some other metals (Zn, K, Ba, Cu, Mn, Ni, Pb, and Cr) were present in lower concentrations. Since XRF analyses present a more superficial scanning of the catalysts’ composition [41], we could observe a difference in the composition of the values and elements detected in Table S2 and Table 2. The MIP OES technique detected a more comprehensive metal composition due to the complete sample digestion in an acid medium and furnished a global sample composition. TSB and RSB presented different contents of these metals, and the biochar RSB showed higher values in good agreement with the ash content (Table 1) [30,39,42]. These results indicate that some of the species were removed from the sewage sludge during its treatment (TSB biochar): especially aluminum, which decreased its concentration [43]. These differences might be related to water-soluble compounds in raw sewage sludge. After the flocculation procedure, some of these compounds are not present in the sewage sludge due to their high solubility and thus reducing the ash content [43]. Besides these differences in concentrations, the structural compositions are similar for both biochars, and the materials agreed with EBC parameters [38]. Next, RSB and TSB biochars were characterized regarding their crystalline phases using the XRD technique, as shown in Fig. 2. A complete identification of the diffraction peaks in the RSB and TSB XRD patterns is problematic since these materials comprise several crystalline phases with overlapped peaks and present low intensities [44,45]. In such a manner, the identification was based primarily on the XRF contents and the use of the software Crystal Match®. The most intense peaks were analyzed and assigned according to the high similarity with the suggested crystallographic cards. In both samples, some phases were identified, such as SiO2 (quartz and cristoballite), calcium sulfate, zinc sulfate and hydroxide, aluminosilicates containing calcium and sodium, titanium dioxide, iron carbide, and silicon carbide. Here is worth mentioning that some of these structures can act as acid sites for FUR valorization: metal oxides which may function as Lewis sites, and aluminosilicates, which act as Brønsted acid sites [46,47]. The textural properties of these biochars were evaluated by N2 physisorption. The isotherms (Fig. S1) were very similar and classified as type II, characteristic of nonporous or macroporous solids with low porosity and slight adsorption [48]. In addition, hysteresis loops were observed at high p/p0 pressures and assigned to the N2 condensation in the mesopores created from interparticular aggregates [49]. Both biochars presented virtually the same B.E.T. specific surface area, and the pore diameters obtained by the B.J.H. method (Fig. S1 and Table 3 ) indicate a large pore distribution, including meso and macropores. It is important to note that sewage sludge biochars often do not display high specific surface areas due to their porous structure. Since these materials are mainly comprised of inorganic compounds, a low amount of pores is formed after the pyrolysis and thus leading to macroporous solids with low surface area [30,42,43,48,50]. In the acidic characterization, a difference in the weight loss between the pure biochars (RSB and TSB) and the biochars containing adsorbed pyridine (RSB – Pyridine, and TSB – Pyridine) was observed. Considering that the pyridine adsorption increased the weight loss value, and from this difference, it was possible to estimate the acidity values (Table 3) [35]. It can be seen from the graphs (Fig. S3) and also from the results presented in Table 3 that RSB presented a more pronounced acidity than TSB. This difference in total acidity is assigned to aspects already addressed in chemical characterization (XRF, MIP OES, and FTIR). The RSB biochar possesses carbonyl groups (associated with carboxylic acid groups) and compounds containing transition metals such as Al and Si (as aluminosilicates), which led to a significant part of the total acidity [37,23]. From the TGA curves (Fig. S3), it is possible to observe a weight loss in the range of 80–100 °C referring to physisorbed gasses and water, having a slight change in the TGA signal for the solid with and without adsorbed pyridine. Comparing the curves for pure biochars and the pyridine adsorbed ones, it is possible to note a signal in the DTA around 400 °C assigned to the oxidation of organic matter. In addition, a new peak was formed around 550 °C for the biochars with adsorbed pyridine. These two differences are attributed to the chemisorption of pyridine on the acid sites; in which the first difference at 400 °C is assigned to the pyridine desorption from weak acid sites (occurring with the oxidation of organic matter), while the weight loss at 550 °C is related to the desorption of pyridine from strong acid sites [35,51]. Furthermore, it is relevant to specify the site type (Brønsted and Lewis), and for this purpose, the FTIR-Py technique was used (Fig. S2). The results show the characteristic bands of Brønsted acidity at 1550 cm−1 and Lewis acidity at 1450 cm−1. These bands refer to the stretching of the C=C bonds of pyridine in the pyridinium ion (interaction with Brønsted acid sites) and the complex formed between pyridine and Lewis acid sites [36]. From Table 3, it is possible to observe a higher acidity for the RSB biochar, which can be assigned to the higher aluminum content, as observed in Table 2. A higher aluminum content might be associated with more aluminosilicates in the RSB biochar and significantly contribute to forming more Brønsted acid sites, as corroborated by a lower L/B ratio. The morphological characteristics of the sewage sludge biochars were evaluated using the SEM-EDS technique and the images shown in Figs. 3 and S4–S7. These images are comprised of grains with heterogeneous sizes and several morphologies and compositions, which is more evident in the chemical mapping images displayed in Figs. S4–S7. Several morphologies were detected, and their composition agrees with the data observed in the XRF and MIP OES results. Furthermore, this heterogeneous composition and morphology are often observed for sewage sludge-derived biochars [52,53]. A dense and wrinkled grain structure comprised of aluminosilicates appears in both biochars, thus corroborating the XRD results (Fig. 2). In addition, the two biochars have grains of micrometers, which directly relates to the heating rate and pyrolysis temperature. It is important to emphasize that the formation of small grains deposited on larger grains occurs due to biochar formation in slow pyrolysis and low temperatures [43]. In TSB SEM images and chemical mapping, it is possible to observe small particles containing titanium and oxygen deposited in larger grains containing sulfur and calcium assigned as calcium sulfate. Regarding the RSB SEM images and chemical mapping, it was possible to observe a porous structure (with diameters in the range of 120–200 nm) comprised of silicon dioxide, typical of the diatomite morphology [54]. In addition, it was observed that some elements typically contribute to the generation of most of the acid sites, such as aluminum, silicon, and iron. The first two elements might significantly contribute to the Brønsted acidity of these biochars, whereas iron can be related to the Lewis acid sites. Also was observed the presence of calcium and magnesium was also observed, corroborating with the XRD patterns. These elements associated with sulfates, carbonates, and oxides might also furnish basic sites for both biochars. The surface chemical composition was analyzed using the XPS technique, and the RSB and TSB survey spectra are presented in Fig. 4. Table S3 shows the surface composition of each biochar material. These results indicate that both surfaces have high carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen concentrations related to the pyrolysis process of the organic matter. In addition, the inorganic ash was also detected by XPS through the peaks assigned to the presence of silicon, aluminum, iron, and calcium, which also were observed in the MIP OES, XRF, and SEM-EDS analyses [23]. Figs. S8 and S9 show the deconvolution of the high-resolution XPS spectra for different signals detected in the survey. The Si2p spectra showed two components, in which the first signal at 100.4 eV for RSB (38.8%) and 98.6 eV (19.9%) for TSB is assigned as elemental silicon [55]. In addition, a signal in 103.2 eV (61.2%, RSB) and 102.2 eV (80.1%, TSB) was detected and is characteristic of aluminosilicates [56]. In the C1s spectra, the deconvolution for both biochars showed different contributions as inorganic carbon in the form of carbide (282.5 eV), sp3 carbon (284.1–284.6 eV), oxygenated organic groups as C=O (288.0–288.1 eV) and COC (286.0 eV), and the aromatic π-π* structure (292.0 eV) [55,57]. Moreover, the signal referring to C=O appears in a higher proportion in the RSB (9.87%) than TSB (5.18%), suggesting a higher amount of carbonyl compounds in the former material, which can significantly contribute to its Brønsted acidity [23]. The signals assigned to inorganic carbon as carbides observed in the XPS spectra were in good agreement with the results shown by the XRD patterns, in which crystalline phases as SiC and Fe3C were observed for both biochars. The signal related to Ca2p for the RSB biochar showed a component attributed to the presence of Ca(OH)2/CaO (346.0 eV, 18.14%), while in the TSB spectrum, this signal was not observed. This Ca(OH)2/CaO signal suggests that RSB also might present basic sites on its surface [57,58]. In the O1s spectra, the RSB and TSB presented three main components: (i) metallic oxides (532.8–529. 9 eV), (ii) oxygen in the organic structure (531.0–530.8 eV), and (iii) silicon oxides as quartz or aluminosilicates (527.9–531.7 eV) [59,60]. In the TSB spectrum, a higher amount of oxygen in the organic structure (31.18%) was observed compared to the RSB material (29.30%), which is in good agreement with a higher C=O content observed in the C1s analyses. In addition, the components related to metallic oxides were 60.92% and 3.77% for RSB and TSB, respectively. A higher amount of metallic oxides in the RSB surface is ascribed to the sewage sludge treatment stage in which the raw biomasses were collected, and no previous treatment was employed [61,62]. The N1s spectra of both biochars presented two components, in which the first is assigned to NC groups (399.3 eV) and the second one to NH groups (400.5 eV) [63]. RSB biochar presented 51.67% for the NH component, whereas the TSB one presented 19.89%. For the component assigned to CN in the biochar structure, the compositions were 48.33% and 80.11% for RSB and TSB, respectively. It is important to note that the higher amount of NH groups in the RSB might act as basic sites in this material. The Fe2p spectra revealed the presence of two species on the surface of both materials and assigned to Fe(II) and Fe(III). The compositions were 61.0% and 86.1% for Fe (II) in the RSB and in the TSB, respectively, while for Fe (III), the compositions were 39.0% and 13.8% [50,64]. It is worth mentioning that only TSB material presented a signal related to the presence of Al. This signal deconvolution revealed only the presence of aluminosilicate, which might be fundamental for creating Brønsted acid sites [56]. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation An initial catalytic run was performed employing RSB and TSB biochars as catalysts following a previously reported procedure [10–12]. Scheme 1 illustrates a simplified reaction pathway for the obtention of the products observed from FUR upgrading. Figs. S10 and S11 show typical chromatograms and the mass spectra used to identify all the products, respectively. Considering all the products mentioned in Scheme 1, all the mechanisms will be explored next. In this context, FUR conversion to FA occurs through catalytic transfer hydrogenation following a mechanism derived from a Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley (MPV) reduction. This mechanism involves the hydrogen transfer as a hydride from isopropanol to FUR and thus yielding the hydrogenated product FA and acetone [65,66]. The mechanistic proposal for forming FBA occurs through an aldol condensation reaction. Initially, as FUR is a non-enolizable aldehyde, the enolate intermediate is formed from the acetone (found in the reaction medium as a product of the MPV reaction). Once the enolate ion is created, the reaction follows a classical condensation mechanism, and FUR undergoes an aldol addition to form the aldol adduct. In addition, at the temperature of a typical reaction (130 °C) this intermediate follows dehydration by the elimination mechanism and thus generates FBA. It is important to note that this mechanistic proposal requires a catalyst that contains acid or basic Brønsted sites to guarantee the enolate ion formation. These sites are present in both biochars and justify the presence of this product for both catalysts. Furyldiene ketones, such as FBA are essential in the fuel industry, and this proposal is highly relevant due to their ability to add carbon to the furanic structure [67]. The IPF obtention occurs through Cannizzaro's mechanism, which occurs in the formation of furoic acid followed by esterification with isopropanol. Non-enolizable aldehydes such as FUR in an alkaline medium are oxidized to their respective esters (if alkoxides are formed) or acids (in the case of hydroxides). For the formation of the IPF in this scenario, the hydroxide anion needs to be generated in the medium. Then a nucleophilic attack on a FUR molecule occurs, producing a charged intermediate. Next, the disproportionation happens when this intermediate donates hydrogen as a hydride to another FUR molecule, thus creating a FA and furoic acid molecule [68]. The presence of the Brønsted acid sites, the excess of isopropanol in the reaction medium, and the favorable temperature condition promote a quick furoic acid conversion to IPF. This reaction follows a classic esterification mechanism in which isopropanol attacks carboxyl moiety and, after successive acid-base reactions, gives rise to IPF. It is interesting to note that GC-MS did not identify furoic acid due to the equilibrium and temperature conditions of the system, which favor its total conversion into other products [69]. An important observation about this mechanistic proposal was reported by Douthwaite and co-workers [68]. The transformation of FUR to its oxidized derivatives usually forms a more significant amount of the oxidized derivative IPF than FA (although the reaction stoichiometry is 1:1). This transformation occurs because FUR reduction to FA is reversible and follows an oxidative dehydrogenation reaction. There are still uncertainties regarding this mechanism, and it is generally accepted that this reaction undergoes a redox process involving metal ions such as Fe+3, Mn+4, and Ti+4. In particular, iron oxide was identified in the biochars studied in this paper, which can significantly contribute to this reversible process [64]. The DFE formation from FA has already been reported in other studies using biochar as a catalyst [25]. Etherification reactions occur in the presence of Brønsted acid sites. The proposed mechanisms for DFE and PMF formation proceed by a classic nucleophilic substitution whereby a carbocation derived from FA suffers a nucleophilic attack by another FA molecule and yields a DFE molecule. When this attack occurs by an isopropanol molecule, the PMF is formed [70]. Unlike the other mentioned reactions, these dehydration reactions occur after MPV reaction, i.e., the FA molecule generated from FUR is the starting material. Therefore, the etherification reaction does not compete for FUR molecules, contrasting with the formation mechanisms of FBA and IPF [68]. Understanding these mechanisms above allows a better comprehension of the conversion and selectivity values presented in Table S4. For instance, when analyzing FUR conversion in both biochars, the data refer to the same trend for acidity. The RSB total acidity led to a higher FUR conversion. Strong basic sites (such as calcium hydroxide or sulfate observed in XPS analyses) also contribute to this result as they promote FUR conversion to FBA and IPF. The lower acidity of the TSB biochar led to a lower conversion of FUR, in which XPS identified no soluble and basic materials. The absence of these sites explains the lack of IPF in the reaction catalyzed by the TSB biochar. Moreover, FBA was identified in the TSB-catalyzed reaction because this product can also be formed through Brønsted acid sites [71]. The studied biochar presented FA as the primary product in the applied reaction conditions. Despite the higher acidity of RSB, its FA selectivity was lower than TSB, and the reaction catalyzed by the former catalysts had an expressive selectivity to DFE due to its higher Brønsted acidity. These observations are correlated with the B/L ratio values (Table 3), where TSB having a lower value of that ration had affected the further reaction of FA to the PMF and DFE ethers [72]. Regarding FBA and IPF, only RSB provided a significant formation of the Cannizzaro's product (IPF), while TSB showed a higher selectivity to FBA. From the discussed characterization data of these biochars, it is possible to infer that IPF formation is related to the presence of calcium hydroxide on the RSB surface [67,68]. Therefore, since the products' mechanisms were proposed and their formation properly elucidated, it is necessary to understand how the reaction parameters (temperature, mass, and isopropanol volume) affect FUR conversion and selectivity to these compounds (Fig. 5 ). It is essential to mention that all the reaction parameters were kept constant, alternating only one at a time, to understand their influence on the process. Other parameters, such as FUR volume (28 μL) and reaction time (24 h), were constant during all the catalytic runs [10–12]. The highest FUR conversion using TSB biochar (Fig. 5b, d, and f) as catalyst was observed in a more concentrated reaction medium, i.e., lower volume of isopropanol, and at 130 °C, and 75 mg of catalyst loading. A higher catalyst loading furnishes more active sites for FUR conversion. In addition, increasing the reaction temperature led to a FUR conversion increase due to the barrier energy in the catalytic hydrogen transfer to form a transition state in which FUR and IPA are bonded to a Lewis acid site [66]. However, the increase in the temperature also led to a lower FA selectivity because this molecule is highly susceptible to reacting with IPA and forming the etherification product PMF [73]. A higher selectivity to FBA was observed at 130 °C, being assigned to the enolate formation in the aldol reaction that is favored at higher temperatures [74]. This product was also preferred when the catalyst loading increased to 75 mg and assigned to a higher amount of Brønsted acid sites to promote the intermediate formation of enolate. The opposite behavior was observed for the RSB biochar (Fig. 5a, c, and d) compared to TSB material. A drastic decrease in FUR conversion was observed at a higher temperature, lower isopropanol volume, and higher catalyst loading. This can be associated with the Cannizzaro's reaction mechanism, in which IPF was the primary product detected for the reaction catalyzed by the RSB biochar. The temperature increase led to a higher IPF selectivity, while a lower FUR conversion was observed. It seems inconsistent that FUR conversion decreased at a higher temperature since this condition is often reported for upgrading this compound (considering an MPV reaction) [10–12]. However, the FA formed in the reaction medium can be oxidatively dehydrogenated back to FUR catalyzed by the iron oxide in this catalyst surface [64]. This FA reconversion to FUR affects its global conversion and thus presents a lower value. In addition, also there was a decrease in FA selectivity due to the Cannizzaro's reaction - competing with the MPV reaction [68]. It is possible to notice that the DFE and PMF selectivities were also influenced by the IPF formation, which is assigned to the low availability of FA in the medium as it is oxidized back to FUR [75]. Since RSB biochar is more acidic than TSB, an increase in the catalyst loading from 25 to 75 mg led to a higher number of active sites to promote the conversion of FA to FUR, thus representing a marked decrease in the global transformation of the latter compound. A more concentrated reaction medium led to a higher selectivity for the MPV products FA and PMF. On the other hand, a diluted reaction medium led to a marked decrease in the FUR conversion and favored the formation of IPF [10–12]. Here it is worth mentioning that despite low FUR conversion values mainly observed for both biochars compared to conventional catalysts described in the literature for this compound upgrading, in this study, we are suggesting a new application of metal-contaminated solids created in sewage treatment processes. The specialized literature for FUR conversion in high selectivity to FA often employs zeolites [30], supported metal oxides [26] and other materials that lead to the quantitative conversion of this reactant [76,18]. However, these materials might process sustainability drawbacks since several synthesis steps are used, and some of them can use molecular hydrogen for this conversion. In that way, using a biochar residue is a step forward for a more sustainable obtention of FA and other value-added compounds. After evaluating the influence of reaction parameters on the FUR conversion and product selectivities, the recyclabilities of the biochars RSB and TSB were assessed, as shown in Fig. 6 . Both biochars presented a marked decrease in FUR conversion for the reuse reactions, in which the RSB biochar presented the highest deactivation degree. It is essential to mention that none of the catalysts were washed or thermally treated after the catalytic runs. In contrast, the literature often reports these treatments, but we decided not to apply them for simplicity of reuse [29,73]. The deactivation of these catalysts might be inferred to occur through two main mechanisms: active phase leaching and polymerization product deposition over the catalyst surface [77]. The latter is well reported in the literature for FUR conversion through acid-catalyzed reactions and aldol condensation [74]. In this sense, we performed characterization studies in the recovered biochars and the reaction medium after the reuse reactions to investigate possible leaching of the active phase. Fig. S12 presents the XRD patterns of the fresh and recovered biochars after the reuse reactions. It is possible to observe the intensity decrease of some peaks assigned to SiO2, α-Fe2O3, CaSO4, and gaultite, thus suggesting the potential leaching of these compounds to the reaction medium. The reaction media were recovered, the organic solvent evaporated, resuspended in water, and followed by MIP OES analyses (Table S5). It can be observed that the active phase from both biochars suffered leaching to the reaction media, in which Al, Ca, Fe, K and Zn were detected in higher amounts. However, no differences were observed in XRD patterns assigned to Al and K crystalline phases. The humin formation over both biochars was analyzed using FTIR, TGA, and N2-physisorption (Figs. S13–S15). In the FTIR spectra (Fig. S13), most of the bands observed for the fresh catalyst were also observed after the reuse reactions, suggesting no degradation of the biochars’ organic structure. However, the rising of new bands in the region between 3000 and 3500 cm−1 and 1700–1800 cm−1 might be associated with the formation of humins. These two regions are typically used in the literature to monitor the humin formation over solid acid catalysts [78]. However, TGA analyses (Fig. S14) show that even after the reuse cycles, the formation of carbonaceous compounds was not significant. There was a slight difference in weight loss of 5% between fresh TSB and after reuse; for the RSB this difference was 3%. These differences are directly related to an increase in the organic fraction of biochar at the expense of the deposition of humins on the surface, thus corroborating with the FTIR results [23]. Regarding the N2 physisorption data (Fig. S15), the isotherms kept the same profile as the fresh biochars. Consequently, they are classified as type II, revealing no significant changes in their porous structure occurred after the reuse reactions [48]. Regarding the specific surface areas, the RSB biochar after the reuse showed virtually the same value compared to the fresh sample (9.5 m2.g−1), while the TSB after reuse there was a slight increase 13.0 m2/g, in which this increase can be related to the deposition of humin on the catalyst surface [79]. Considering the FUR conversion decrease and the characterizations done and discussed above of the reused biochars, it is proposed that both humin deposition and active phase leaching coincide. Despite the partial biochars deactivation in the FUR upgrading reactions, it is essential to highlight that a more sustainable use for sewage sludge was proposed, thus opening a broad range of opportunities for value-added compounds obtention. 4 Conclusions In this study, two biochars from sewage sludge were obtained through the pyrolysis process, extensively characterized, and tested in furfural upgrading. The characterization showed that these materials have a mixed organic matrix composition and inorganic compounds, contributing to Lewis and Brønsted acid sites and basicity. The catalytic runs showed that these materials could promote the production of different value-added products, and four mechanisms were proposed to explain their formation. In particular, furfuryl alcohol was detected as the primary product, and ethers, ketones, and ester derived from furfural were observed by GC-MS. Biochar derived from raw sewage sludge showed higher acidity than treated sewage sludge. Consequently, the former material showed a higher furfural conversion due to its higher ash content of inorganic compounds, which furnish a significant part of its acidity. However, the TSB material presented a higher selectivity to furfuryl alcohol due to its lower B/L ratio, which limited the furfuryl alcohol etherification process. Furthermore, the presence of basic sites led to the formation of other value-added compounds, such as isopropyl furan-2-carboxylate and (E)-4-(furan-2-yl)but-3-en-2-one. The evaluation of reaction parameters showed that treated sewage sludge biochar favored the formation of furfuryl alcohol while the biochar derived from raw sewage sludge led to the formation of isopropyl furan-2-carboxylate. These particularities are closely related to the mechanism of these reactions and the structure of the biochar catalysts. In addition, the reuse of both biochars displayed a marked decrease in furfural conversion, which was assigned to the partial leaching of the active phase as observed by MIP OES measurements and the formation of humin as evidenced by FTIR and TGA analyses. This study demonstrated the favorable characteristics of sewage sludge-derived biochars to be used as catalysts for both acid (Lewis and Brønsted) and base-promoted reactions for upgrading lignocellulosic biomass-derived compounds such as the platform furfural molecule. Although some deactivation was observed, it is noteworthy that even after five reuse reactions, the building-block furfuryl alcohol was the primary product obtained. Moreover, the search for new sewage sludge applications represents an advance in solving an environmental issue while also moving forward in achieving more sustainable and cheaper catalysts for producing bio-derived compounds. coredata.dc:description: Furfural is an important biobased building block molecule to produce several value-added compounds for the fine chemical industry, biofuels, and biopolymers through a catalytic pathway. Developing cheaper and more sustainable catalysts to promote furfural conversion reactions is imperative to meet the Green Chemistry principles and obtain biobased products through greener routes. In this sense, sewage sludge-derived biochars emerge as promising materials that catalyze furfural conversion reactions since they possess acid and basic surface sites due to their high metal content and organic structure. This paper reports the employment of two sewage sludge-derived biochars as catalysts for furfural conversion, an encouraging application for these solids with severe environmental concerns. These materials were fully characterized regarding their composition, structure, textural, morphological, acidic, and surface properties, displaying the presence of acid (Lewis and Brønsted) and basic sites. These biochars presented good activity for converting furfural (26.5–68.8%) and high selectivity to furfuryl alcohol (43.6–90.6%). In addition, other value-added products were observed, such as furfural-derived ethers, ester, and ketone.
coredata.dc:title: Metal-contaminated biochars as cheap and more sustainable catalysts for furfural conversion to value-added compounds
